newsitem.title: USA: BankAmerica board meets Feb on repurchases.
newsitem.headline: BankAmerica board meets Feb on repurchases.

text.p: BankAmerica Corp chief financial officer Michael O'Neill said the board will meet in early February to consider dividend and repurchase recommendations.
Earlier, BankAmerica said it repurchased 4.7 million shares in the fourth quarter. O'Neill noted the company has $800 million of authority left in the stock repurchase plan.

On a conference call with reporters, O'Neill called the repurchase program a default strategy. "We believe that we can deploy our capital in more shareholder friendly ways than through acquisitions," he said.
During the conference call, O'Neill also cited a pickup in California loan demand during the fourth quarter, that is expected to continue.
"I'm happy to see we've seen a long-awaited pickup in California loan demand and we think that bodes well for the future," said O'Neill.

He said 30 percent of BankAmerica's domestic loan growth in the fourth quarter occurred in California, both in consumer and commercial loans. Domestic loans grew about $3.0 billion to $139 billion since the quarter ended September 30.
In December, BankAmerica announced it would cut 3,700 jobs resulting in fourth quarter restructuring charge in order to cut costs in certain underperforming areas.

O'Neill said BankAmerica continues to study each asset and division. "This process is ongoing and will continue in perpetuity. I suspect there will be actions that will come out but none at this point that will be tangible," he said.
Additionally, O'Neill said BankAmerica has no plans to acquire a brokerage in California or elsewhere at this point.
Several analysts have said BankAmerica has indicated an interest in making such an acquisition.
Earlier, BankAmerica reported fourth quarter income rose to $1.93 per share to $1.74 per share.
Net income rose to $747 million from $704 million.
The earnings topped First Call mean estimate of $1.90 a share.
